e4: Switching to the new policy ensures that reported earnings are accurate and unbiased, reinforcing the company's credibility. It reduces legal risks associated with misleading financial reporting and fosters trust with all investors by preventing any misinformation. Although there might be some initial confusion among investors, clear communication can mitigate misunderstandings. Over time, this shift enhances transparency and aligns with ethical standards, supporting long-term investor confidence and stability.
e5: An ethical reporting policy provides accurate, clear, and unbiased financial data, ensuring transparency and honesty to all stakeholders. It should prevent any potential manipulation or misrepresentation of financial performance. Ethical policies also involve fair treatment to all types of investors, reducing information asymmetry and ensuring informed decision-making. Communicating changes clearly and contextually aids in maintaining investor trust, embracing accountability and integrity as core principles of ethical financial management.
e6: What communication strategies will be implemented to ensure investors fully understand the transition to the new policy? How does management plan to address potential market reactions or misunderstandings? Additionally, what measures will be taken to monitor the impact of this change on retail versus institutional investors?
